title: Structural and Biochemical Characterization of MERS-CoV Polymerase
content: Coronaviruses (CoVs) are a subfamily of viruses that cause diseases in mammals and birds. They encode their genomes in one, large single-stranded, positive-sense RNA. Viruses of the CoV subfamily encode 16 non-structural proteins (nsp1-16) that are responsible for RNA replication and transcription [1]. RNA synthesis is an essential process for the viral life cycle and uses a virally-encoded replication-transcription complex containing nsp12 (the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRP)) and cofactors nsp7 and nsp8. Unlike the viral structural proteins, nsps are better conserved among the coronaviruses; hence, the findings from one genus can be applied across the coronavirus subfamily.
